case_title: IRSHAD KHAN vs GOHAR RAHMAN KHATTAK, ADVOCATE

accussed_details.name: Gohar Rahman Khattak
allegation: Cheating and deception under the guise of legal profession

complaint_summary: Irshad Khan alleged that Gohar Rahman Khattak demanded Rs. 80,000 as bribe for securing acquittal in a murder case. Later, Rs. 70,000 was returned, but Rs. 10,000 remained unpaid. The respondent was accused of professional misconduct under the Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973.
investigation_summary: The Disciplinary Committee initiated proceedings against the respondent. Evidence was recorded, and the respondent absented himself. The case was referred to the Tribunal for final adjudication.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal found the respondent guilty of professional misconduct. It held that the respondent's actions violated professional ethics and undermined public trust in the legal profession. The respondent was suspended from practice for two years and ordered to pay Rs. 20,000 as costs.
punishment: Suspension from practice for two years and payment of Rs. 20,000 as costs.
legal_arguments: Application of Civil Procedure Code provisions is limited to securing witness attendance.
Professional misconduct cannot be compromised or withdrawn as per legal precedents.
Violation of professional ethics under Rules 134, 172, and 175-A of Pakistan Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Rules, 1973.
statutes: Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973
Pakistan Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Rules, 1973
witnesses: Other witnesses recorded by Disciplinary Committee

witness_statement.Irshad Khan: Stated under oath that Rs. 80,000 was paid to the respondent for bribing the Presiding Officer, which was later partially returned.

legal_terms.Professional Misconduct: Violation of ethical standards by a legal practitioner.

words_and_phrases.Professional Ethics: Standards of conduct expected from legal practitioners.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves allegations of bribery and professional misconduct against an advocate. The Tribunal found the respondent guilty, emphasizing the importance of maintaining public trust in the legal profession.

legal_basis: Section 44 of Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973

key_arguments.respondent: Complaint should be dismissed as withdrawn under Civil Procedure Code provisions.
key_arguments.complainant: No objection to withdrawal if Rs 10,000 is paid.

precedent_case.title: Muhammad Amin v. M. Asghar Khokhar, Advocate
precedent_case.principle: Compromise does not erase professional misconduct.
